results.title: Julius Caesar: the rise of the Roman Empire
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Deneen
results.brief_description: The role of Julius Caesar in transforming Rome from a city Republic to a world empire; the arrest of power from the Senate by the triumvirate; Caesar’s military conquests culminating in his emergence as the single ruler of the Empire. He inaugurated reforms of the legal system, economy and public works. In 44 BC Julius Caesar was murdered.

results.title: Julius Caesar: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Peter Seabourne
results.brief_description: A talented English company performs key scenes in this abbreviated version which, however, preserves the sense of tragedy of the full-length drama. Brief narrative bridges connect the scenes, which offers the first-time reader an opportunity to acquire a grasp of the main themes and action, and enrich his understanding and appreciation of the play.

results.title: Julius Caesar [Excerpts]
results.brief_description: So that people who have had no opportunity of seeing Shakespeare’s plays staged may see leading English actors in a full-scale stage production, these excerpts from “Julius Caesar” have been filmed, sponsored by the British Council. The cast includes Leo Genn as Marc Antony; Felix Aylmer as Brutus; and John Slater, Emrys Jones, Frederick Cooper, Ben Williams, Grqace Allardyce, Arthur Hambling and Sydney Monckton among the other players.

results.title: Juliette Ou la Clef des Songes = juliette or the key of dreams
results.brief_description:
Michel, a prisonner, escapes from his cell every night in dreams to be reunited with his beloved Juliette. In his pursuit of Juliette, Michel arrives in a god-forsaken village where all the inhabitants seem to have lost their memory. Continuity between Occupation and postwar cinema, though great, was far from absolute. At the level of film genre, the most notable change was the rapid decline of one of Occupation’s favored subjects: the fantastic. Stories of ghosts, prophetic dreams, devils and demons, love potions, and the like had greatly appealed to French filmmakers and audiences in the spiritual half-light of the occupied country. (…) The last major film of this trend, and of the period’s strong penchant for the fantastic, was Carne’s ‘Juliette ou la cle des songes’, a work which would certainly have a better reception had the director been able to make it when he first wanted to, in 1942. In 1951 it was a terrible anachronism, received with great hostility at the Cannes film festival and closing after a few weeks of mediocre box office returns, despite having Gerard Philipe (by then a big star) in the male lead.” Alan Williams. “Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1951: Best music for Joseph Kosma.

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Marcel Carne ; writer, Georges Neveux, Marcel Carne, Jacques Viot ; photography ; Henri Alekan ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Suzanne Cloutier, Gerard Philippe, Gabrielle Fontan, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Yves Robert.

results.title: Julie, your best just isn't good enough
results.brief_description: Julie left school early and as been in and out of jobs for four years. She has been unemployed for tem months and is willing to take any job. She talks about the dole, what she does with her money and about her parents.
results.title_for_label: Julie, your best just isn’t good enough

results.title: Julia: critical moments in teaching (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Calvin Productions, United States. Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare, David Gliessman and Don G. Williams
results.brief_description: Julia, a naturally retiring child, becomes withdrawn in class. The school psychologist tests her and finds she has a hearing impairment. He recommends keeping Julia in her present class. Her teacher is suddenly confronted with the realisation that she has primary responsibility for Julia’s education. What steps should she take to help her?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Calvin Productions, United States. Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare, David Gliessman and Don G. Williams

results.title: Jules Verne
results.brief_description:
Jules Verne had three passions in life: the sea, music and freedom. The passion for the sea started during his childhood in Nantes, in the Quartier de l’Ile Feydeau, filled with memeories of explorers and slave traders. Destined to become a lawyer, Verne is sent to Paris where he begins to write. His writings are highly influenced by the industrial revolution and the belief in the power of the machine to transform the world.

Credits: Director, Jean Vidal ; writer, Yolande Cassin.
Cast: Daniel Ivernel [narration only].

results.title: Jules et Jim = Jules and Jim (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Carrosse, SEDIF and Francois Truffaut
results.brief_description:
The story of a menage-a-trois in the years around World War I is distanced by the narrator who makes the viewer continually aware of the artifice involved in its telling. Truffaut drew on incidents in his own life in developing Roche’s novel in a personal way. He identified Jim with Roche and Jules with himself. Their discovery of Catherine is symptomatic of the confusion between art and life which pervades the protagonists’ lives. The narrative, punctuated by cinematic allusions, is marked by a wide range of techniques and rapid shifts in mood from pathos to whimsy. Also avaiable on VHS and laserdisc.

Credits: Director, Francois Truffaut ; writer, Francois Truffaut, Jean Gruault ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Georges Delerue ; editor, Claudine Bouche.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Oscar Werner, Henri Serre, Marie Dubois.

results.title: Judy Grinham
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “British Sporting Personalities”.
The swimming career of Judy Grinham turned on her decision, when only twelve years of age, to concentrate on her backstroke, and on her partnership with the great swimming coach, Reg Laxton. Shows her racing performance in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and the 1958 Commonwealth Games and a glimpse of her private life as well.
